text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I'm Ann ReardonÂ 
and today I have something exciting,Â Â

it's new to me but it's very old ... it'sÂ 
called Domestic Cookery by a Lady. Now ifÂ Â

we have a look inside we can see it was givenÂ 
to a beloved wife in 1845. The first edition ofÂ Â

this book was printed 216 years ago and theyÂ 
cost a lot of money to get a first edition,Â Â

this is actually a 67th edition and it's datedÂ 
1843 so this one is nearly 180 years old.Â Â

So who wrote it? Early editions just sayÂ 
'by a lady' which was common at the timeÂ Â

and to give you some insight into that let me readÂ 
you this ... while man has been characterized asÂ Â

a cooking animal the capabilities of a woman toÂ 
undertake even the minor branches of the culinaryÂ Â

art have been doubted and denied all gastronomesÂ 
of a refined grade unite in denouncing she-cooksÂ Â

and M Ude when he wishes to express his contemptÂ 
for any commonplace dish says a woman can do it.Â Â

An observation of Dr Johnson shows up on how veryÂ 
low scale that learned person rated the culinaryÂ Â

talents of the sex women he remarks can spin veryÂ 
well but they cannot write a book of cookery.Â Â

Well I'd like to disagree with that one ğŸ¤¨ and evenÂ 
this excerpt goes on to disagree with it. WomenÂ Â

have written more extraordinary things since hisÂ 
time and Mrs Rundle's excellent work a work whichÂ Â

far surpassed all its predecessors shows that theÂ 
doctor did not do justice to feminine ingenuity.Â Â

They were having to defend the fact that theÂ 
cookbook was written by a woman! This bookÂ Â

actually sold more than half a million copies inÂ 
her lifetime and if we go back a page it actuallyÂ Â

says that this little work would have been aÂ 
treasure to herself the author when she first setÂ Â

out in life and therefore she hopes that it mayÂ 
prove useful to others in that expectation it'sÂ Â

given to the public and she will receive from itÂ 
no emolument (now that means no profit she wouldÂ Â

not get paid for this book) so she trusts that itÂ 
will escape with no sense here or no disapproval.Â Â

So she gave this book of recipes to a friend JohnÂ 
Murray who was a publisher and he published it andÂ Â

put himself down as the copyright owner. ExtraÂ 
recipes have been added into this book with eachÂ Â

new edition but original ones are still marked byÂ 
ER if they were by Mrs rundle so let's make one ofÂ Â

those let's try this lemon sponge. To a pint ofÂ 
water put an ounce of isinglass. Isinglass comesÂ Â

from the air bladder of fish. Flat fish like thisÂ 
pomfret don't have one but bony fish like thisÂ Â

schnapper do. If we take off the fillet then liftÂ 
up the ribs and pull this bit out of the way ohÂ Â

i don't really like raw fish, i'm sorry it'sÂ 
a bit gross but this is the air bladder hereÂ Â

and it's used by fish to control their buoyancyÂ 
so they can stay at a depth that they want toÂ Â

without floating up or sinking down and thatÂ 
makes swimming a lot more efficient for them.Â Â

I'm going to cut two of these up i'm not reallyÂ 
sure how much i should use here. Sturgeon fishÂ Â

are the most commonly used ones for isinglass andÂ 
it's still used today in beers and wines to makeÂ Â

it clear to clarify it and so why do we need themÂ 
for this dessert? Well it's going to help it setÂ Â

so we put them in a pot with some water and simmerÂ 
it for several hours until only a small amount ofÂ Â

the liquid is left and we'll just strain that intoÂ 
a bowl. After leaving it in the fridge overnightÂ Â

you can see it sit like a very firm jelly. NowÂ 
I'm not sure if they were making this usingÂ Â

fresh like I just did or using dried so that makesÂ 
the quantities quite tricky but it does say weÂ Â

need the rind of a lemon the juice of three halfÂ 
a pound of sugar and the isinglass. I'm going toÂ Â

have to warm that up again just to melt it againÂ 
in the recipe they just had it warm from theÂ Â

beginning they didn't let it set in the fridge butÂ 
I wanted to show you that it sets like gelatin.Â Â

Now we need to add the white of one egg andÂ 
whisk until it's white and thick. The vintageÂ Â

egg beaters that some of you might be familiarÂ 
with were not invented for another 40 years soÂ Â

we're just stuck with a whisk! Electric beatersÂ 
would be another 40 years after that becauseÂ Â

there was no electricity yet. Once that is whiteÂ 
and thick I guess we just tip it into a glassÂ Â

now I've also repeated this recipe but usedÂ 
gelatin instead of the fish air bladders soÂ Â

that we can compare how they set. WhatÂ 
else can we make? This one caught my eyeÂ Â

egg mince pies it just sounds weird it hasÂ 
ER there so we know it was by Eliza Rundle...Â Â

it says boil six eggs hard and cut them small.Â 
Now i've boiled these and let them cool i've neverÂ Â

seen a dessert recipe with boiled eggs in it andÂ 
that's why i thought this would be interesting. ItÂ Â

said to cut them small so hopefully thatÂ 
is small enough. I've weighed the eggsÂ Â

so i could then measure double the quantity ofÂ 
chopped suet which is what it said we needed nextÂ Â

this is sewage so it is fat from red meatÂ 
like lamb or beef. This really seems like aÂ Â

lot of meat fat for inside a pie. Then it saysÂ 
add a pound of currants half a pound of choppedÂ Â

raisins and the peel of a lemon grated. OkayÂ 
so let's chop some raisins and add those inÂ Â

next the currants and some grated lemon rind.Â 
I do wonder if the currants were not driedÂ Â

currants like nowadays if you see currants in aÂ 
recipe it does mean dried currants but back thenÂ Â

I'm wondering if they meant the berries likeÂ 
red currants. Next it says add half a nutmeg aÂ Â

teaspoon of allspice and a little salt. That's theÂ 
grated nutmeg the allspice and a pinch of salt.Â Â

Now it says we need sugar candied lemonÂ 
peel and two glasses of sweet wine.Â Â

It didn't actually say how much sugar to add soÂ 
i'm just guessing here and there's no quantityÂ Â

for the candied lemon peel either so i'll justÂ 
put some in it's a bit bitter so i won't putÂ Â

too much on and then the two glasses of wine andÂ 
that's it. It doesn't say what to do with thisÂ Â

but it is in the section of pies so i assume weÂ 
mix it all together and then line a pie dish withÂ Â

pastry and tip it in. I can't help but think thatÂ 
once all this suet melts it's going to be an oilyÂ Â

mess but perhaps it's supposed to be served coldÂ 
once it's baked so maybe i'll try that. I didÂ Â

some research on Mrs Rundell and there's not a lotÂ 
about her that has been recorded. I couldn't evenÂ Â

find any portraits of her, she's a best-sellingÂ 
cookbook author and there's no information.Â Â

She was born Maria Eliza Kettlebee in 1745 she wasÂ 
an only child and she was described as a woman ofÂ Â

wealth. When she was 21 years old she marriedÂ 
a surgeon called Thomas Rundell which is whereÂ Â

she gets her last name obviously. Rundell wasÂ 
one of 16 children and one of Thomas's brothersÂ Â

worked at a jewelers in London and heÂ 
borrowed money off Eliza and ThomasÂ Â

to buy into the store with his business partnerÂ 
Bridge. Maria and Thomas went on to have two sonsÂ Â

and three daughters and when she was 50 sadly herÂ 
husband passed away. She then apparently traveledÂ Â

and lived with her daughters and obviously wroteÂ 
books. It says here the authoress Mrs Rundell,Â Â

sister of the eminent jeweler on Ludgate HillÂ 
was afterwards induced to accept the sum ofÂ Â

2000 guineas from the publisher. With inflationÂ 
that's equivalent to about 188,000 pounds todayÂ Â

which is a lot of money and it sounds so nice whenÂ 
it says she was induced to accept it when in factÂ Â

she took the publisher to court when she was 74Â 
years old over the rights to the book and as aÂ Â

result of that he had to pay her the money. One ofÂ 
their sons ended up working at the jewelry storeÂ Â

on Ludgate Hill with his uncle so it was renamedÂ 
Rundell and Bridge and Rundell. The store wasÂ Â

the principal jewelers and goldsmiths for theÂ 
royal family making everything from crowns toÂ Â

candelabras this was a very successful jewelersÂ 
and it may have so outweighed the success ofÂ Â

the cookbook that there's more writtenÂ 
about the jewelry store than there isÂ Â

about Eliza Rundell. Estate Diamond Jewelry inÂ 
New York who specializes in rare vintage ringsÂ Â

have sent me a very old ring for this video. TheÂ 
ring is actually from England originally i don'tÂ Â

think it's from Rundell and Bridge but i'll getÂ 
a close-up so you can see the hand carving on theÂ Â

side which is indicative of its age this was veryÂ 
common in that period. Vintage rings like thisÂ Â

are one of a kind there isn't another one thatÂ 
looks the same as this because it is handmade.Â Â

You can see on the inside it says 1854 but to beÂ 
honest anyone could engrave a ring so you reallyÂ Â

need an experienced jeweler that you can trustÂ 
to be able to date old jewelry like this for you.Â Â

Let's make one more recipe and then tasteÂ 
them all ... here we have a sponge cake byÂ Â

Mrs Rundell and it says we need eight eggs halfÂ 
the whites three-quarters of a pound of sugarÂ Â

half a pound of flour a quarter of a pint ofÂ 
water and the peel of a lemon and mix as follows.Â Â

Now, this is interesting to me becauseÂ 
this is the first old recipe i've seen thatÂ Â

has the ingredients listed first and then theÂ 
directions usually it's all just mixed through.Â Â

Overnight pare a good sized lemonÂ 
thin and put the peel into waterÂ Â

and when about to make the cake put the sugarÂ 
into a saucepan and pour the water and the lemonÂ Â

peel into it and let it stand by the fire to getÂ 
hot. Break the eggs into a deep earthen vesselÂ Â

that has been made quite hot whisk the eggs forÂ 
a few minutes with a whisk that has been wellÂ Â

soaked in water. I'm not quite sureÂ 
why the whisk was supposed to be wetÂ Â

but you might be able to tell me in the comments.Â 
Make the sugar and water boil up and pour itÂ Â

boiling hot over the eggs and continue to whiskÂ 
them briskly for about a quarter of an hour, wow!

This is really hard work even swapping betweenÂ 
Dave and me, a quarter of an hour whisking is aÂ Â

long time ğŸ˜° or until they become quite thick andÂ 
white which is proof of their lightness. HaveÂ Â

flour well dried and quite warm from the fire andÂ 
just stir it lightly in and put the cake into tinsÂ Â

lined with white paper and send them immediatelyÂ 
to be baked in a moderately hot oven. These haveÂ Â

so much air in them that they didn't need bakingÂ 
powder they rose up nicely as they cooked but thenÂ Â

shrunk back down a little. Well I think it'sÂ 
time to taste all these goodies ... Here we go...

It's a bit sort of chewyÂ 
and dry, um, flavor is okayÂ Â

but yeah just the texture's not quite it's notÂ 
quite Ann Reardon. It's almost as if you took aÂ Â

regular sponge and you left it out overnight andÂ 
then you came back to it the next day like it'sÂ Â

not bad and it's not stale but it's definitely aÂ 
bit too tough and also maybe slightly less sweetÂ Â

than what I would expect from a spongeÂ 
cake but it's certainly edible. And nowÂ Â

on to the boiled egg and suet fruit pie.Â 
This looks possibly more dangerous...

Um, all right I'm just delaying becauseÂ 
I don't really want to eat it...

I don't mind it's sort of fruity and it'sÂ 
got a little bit of a different texture to itÂ Â

but it's quite pleasant, feels a bit umÂ 
sort of sticks to the top of your mouthÂ Â

a little bit sort of oily or buttery.
It kind of tastes how it looks it's justÂ Â

a lot of raisins in some pastry it might beÂ 
better hot could I taste can I taste it warm?

Well it's kind of falling apart now that it'sÂ 
hot. What is in here, is it actual mince?

I liked it better when it wasn't hot. ğŸ˜‚
Mix them with double the quantity ofÂ Â

chopped suet ... oh so it's likeÂ 
just pure fat. Meat fat yeah.Â

What are you doing with the eggs cause it doesn'tÂ 
really taste like egg. It's got hard-boiled eggsÂ Â

chopped up that's what those white bits are.Â 
Maybe that's why it tasted worse when it was hot.Â Â

The lemon dessert settled out into twoÂ 
layers with the froth on the top andÂ Â

the lemony bit down the bottom the one setÂ 
with the air bladders of fish settled outÂ Â

more so than the one with the gelatin theÂ 
foam was a bit more stable on the gelatin one.Â Â

All right so this is the 200 year old traditionalÂ 
lemon sponge did you say that's what theyÂ Â

called it okay let's have a little taste I'mÂ 
hoping for a lemon meringue pie type of vibe.
Anything from 200 year old can be a little scaryÂ Â

it's, it's kind of liquidy I'm not sure ifÂ 
the setting agent really worked that well...

It tastes fine. That's not bad lemonÂ 
meringue pie-ish minus the pie.Â Â

If there's something weird if they've blendedÂ 
peasant's feet in there or something IÂ Â

can't taste it. I can't imagine having more thanÂ 
about two or three teaspoons before I just turnÂ Â

into a sugary mess. So in that dessert they usedÂ 
the air sacs from fish as the gelling agent.Â Â

Okay. Oh yeah well it still tastes fineÂ 
I would eat it. Air sacks and fish...

no I didn't taste that but it's prettyÂ 
unappealing the thought of it. But theÂ Â

thought of gelatin in itself is unappealingÂ 
that's made from bones and ... Yeah trueÂ Â

true. So so if you didn't taste fishy it'sÂ 
an improvement ... Sure it's an improvement,Â Â

it's an improvement until you find out what'sÂ 
in it. If you'd like to see more recipes fromÂ Â
